Legal_Issue: Likelihood of confusion between 'Pure Life' and 'Life Brand' trademarks
Procedural_Stage: Appeal from Trade Marks Opposition Board to Federal Court
Evidence_Assessment: Distinctiveness of marks, usage history, nature of wares, trade channels, resemblance in appearance or sound
Burden_of_Proof: On Imasco to demonstrate likelihood of confusion
Legal_Rule: Confusion determined by distinctiveness, usage, nature of goods, trade channels, and visual/aural similarity
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, based on statutory interpretation and evidence
Procedural_Issue: Appeal from partial allowance of trademark application
Grounds_for_Claim: Imasco claimed potential consumer confusion due to similar use of 'Life' in branding
Review_Standard: Statutory interpretation and evidentiary review under the Trade Marks Act
Key_Evidence_Considered: Dissimilar mark designs, different first words ('Pure' vs. 'Life'), commonality of word 'Life', differing sales channels
Legal_Framework: Canadian trademark law, specifically the Trade Marks Act
Applicant_Challenge: Overcoming opposition to registration of 'Pure Life'
Defendant_Response: Imasco opposed registration, arguing likelihood of confusion
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, market usage, product packaging, distribution channels
Outcome: Appeal allowed; Sum-Spec granted right to register
Legal_Provision: Sections of the Trade Marks Act relating to confusion and registrability
Claimant_Status: Sum-Spec as applicant for trademark registration
Legal_Provision_Cited: Trade Marks Act – provisions on confusion and distinctiveness
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Allegation of trademark confusion under Section 12(1)(d) or similar
Applicable_Process: Administrative opposition followed by judicial appeal
Governing_Rule: Test for confusion under Canadian trademark law
